item.title: City Room: New York Today: Beware of Leaves
item.description: What you need to know for Tuesday: foliage and trains don’t mix, chilly sunshine and Spider-Man’s final flights.
item.dc:creator: By ANDY NEWMAN

item.title: Blasts at Iranian Embassy in Beirut Kill at Least 23
item.description: Two bombs detonated in Bir Hassan — an area populated by Shiite Muslims — killing at least 23 people, including the Iranian cultural attaché, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD, ANNE BARNARD and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Two men at the scene of two explosions near the Iranian embassy in Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: Storm Brings Flooding and Destruction to Sardinia
item.description: The Italian government declared a state of emergency on the island on Tuesday after a torrential rainstorm killed at least 16 and left countless homeless.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: DealBook: U.S. Poised to Announce $13 Billion JPMorgan Settlement
item.description: The deal with JPMorgan Chase over its mortgage practices, expected as soon as Tuesday, will detail how a $13 billion payout will be divvied up.
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)|FMCC|OTCBB
Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
item.media:description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. played a hands-on role in settlement talks with JPMorgan Chase's chief executive.

item.title: A Diver’s Rise, and Swift Death, at the Limits of a Growing Sport
item.description: Nicholas Mevoli’s rise from novice to record-holder in little more than a year serves both as an inspiration and as a dire warning to divers whose stars rise as the depths they reach plunge.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN BRANCH, ADAM SKOLNICK, WILLIAM J. BROAD and MARY PILON
item.media:credit: Lia Hyun-Joo Barrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicholas Mevoli on Sunday upon surfacing from a record attempt. He died a short time later.

item.title: It’s the Economy: Why Is Turkey Cheaper When Demand Is Higher?
item.description: It’s a trend that seems to defy Econ 101: In early November, the price of frozen whole turkeys drops. Economists can’t agree why.
item.dc:creator: By CATHERINE RAMPELL

item.title: Officials Were Warned About Health Site Woes
item.description: A report prepared in late March by an outside management consultant said a “lack of transparency and alignment on critical issues” was threatening progress.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By SHARON LaFRANIERE and ERIC LIPTON
item.media:description: President Obama took responsibility last week for the troubled rollout of the online federal health insurance marketplace.

item.title: Explosions Near Iranian Embassy in Beirut Kill 7
item.description: Two explosions struck Tuesday near the Iranian Embassy in the Lebanese capital of Beirut, killing at least seven people, wounding scores and causing wide damage to the mission and nearby buildings.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Country at a Crossroads: In the Middle of Mexico, a Middle Class Is Rising
item.description: In Guanajuato, Mexico, foreign investment and local enrichment are creating a young, upwardly mobile middle class.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Memo From France: Hollande’s Assertive Role in Foreign Policy Is a Good Fit for France
item.description: President François Hollande of France is building a far more confident image abroad than at home, a striking contrast that shows how much his nation values a role in world affairs.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: President François Hollande, left, at the Hall of Remembrance at the Yad Vashem Holocaust museum in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: Hollywood Studios Facing Upheaval at Highest Levels
item.description: A rolling realignment, seemingly change for change’s sake, has knocked out executives and producers at several major studios.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY and BROOKS BARNES
item.media:credit: James Best Jr./The New York Times

item.title: His Honor? Toronto’s Mayor Rampages On, to City’s Shame
item.description: Despite the bizarre antics of Mayor Rob Ford, most notably his use of crack, he will likely remain at the helm of Canada’s largest city until his term ends next year.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto at a council meeting on Monday.

item.title: Latest Release of Documents on N.S.A. Includes 2004 Ruling on Email Surveillance
item.description: The Obama administration on Monday made public a trove of documents, including a court ruling that approved a program to track Americans’ emails during the Bush administration.
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and JAMES RISEN

item.title: ‘Spider-Man’ to Close on Broadway
item.description: A somewhat revamped version of the musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” is planned for Las Vegas in 2015.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK HEALY
item.media:description: A scene with the original cast of "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark" at the Foxwoods Theater in New York.

item.title: DealBook: John Edwards Revisits His Past, Hanging Law Shingle Again
item.description: The path back for Mr. Edwards began when his legal troubles ended last year. Prosecutors had charged him with misusing nearly $1 million in campaign donations.
item.dc:creator: By PETER LATTMAN and KIM SEVERSON
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, David Kirby, John Edwards and his daughter Cate. The three will work at the new firm, Edwards Kirby.

item.title: Split on Accord on Iran Strains U.S.-Israel Ties
item.description: As the United States and its allies consider an accord to freeze Tehran’s nuclear program, divergent views have deeply politicized the question of whether it should be termed a good deal or a bad one.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Hamid Foroutan/Iranian Students News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A heavy-water nuclear reactor near the town of Arak, if operating, could provide Iran with a steady supply of plutonium, the fuel North Korea and Pakistan have used for their arsenals.

item.title: Obama Pick for Court Is 3rd in a Row Blocked by Republicans
item.description: In blocking Judge Robert L. Wilkins’s nomination, Senate Republicans on Monday denied President Obama his third pick in recent weeks to fill a vacancy on the nation’s most powerful and prestigious appeals court.
item.dc:creator: By JEREMY W. PETERS
item.media:description: Robert L. Wilkins, left, with President Obama and other nominees in June, was picked to fill one of three vacancies on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

item.title: Europeans Fault American Safety Effort in Bangladesh
item.description: Europeans claimed that Americans were trying to avoid paying for safety improvements at factories and criticized an independent inspection effort by Walmart.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:description: Garment workers demanding higher wages in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Nov. 8. There are 1,600 garment factories in the country.

item.title: Power Still Out for Thousands After Tornadoes Pound Midwest
item.description: Illinois was hit especially hard by tornadoes that tore through the Midwest on Sunday, killing at least six people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN YACCINO and JOHN SCHWARTZ
item.media:description: The storm system’s path on Sunday in central Illinois.

item.title: DealBook: Regulators See Value in Bitcoin, and Investors Hasten to Agree
item.description: Federal officials told a Senate hearing that virtual currencies like bitcoin offered real benefits for the financial system.
item.dc:creator: By NATHANIEL POPPER
item.media:description: Jennifer Shasky Calvery, left, with Mythili Raman and Edward Lowery on Monday at a hearing in Washington.

item.title: Prosecutor in Racially Charged Shooting Case Near Detroit Is No Stranger to Spotlight
item.description: Kym L. Worthy, who is viewed as meticulous, blunt and unshakable — sometimes to a fault — is prosecuting the fatal shooting of a black woman by a white man in a Detroit suburb.
item.dc:creator: By MONICA DAVEY
item.media:description: Kym L. Worthy, center, Wayne County’s top prosecutor, on Friday announced second-degree murder charges in the shooting of a 19-year-old woman by a suburban Detroit homeowner.

item.title: Cause of Gas Leak That Killed 2 Colorado Miners Is Sought
item.description: Inspectors said the two men died of carbon monoxide poisoning Sunday at a mining site in southwestern Colorado that has had a troubled safety record.
item.dc:creator: By DAN FROSCH

item.title: Princeton University to Use Foreign Vaccine
item.description: The meningitis vaccine, which has been approved in Europe and Australia, is expected to be available on campus at no cost in early December.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Seven people at Princeton University this year have contracted a strain of meningitis not covered by the usual vaccine.

item.title: Slowdown in Carbon Emissions Worldwide, but Coal Burning Continues to Grow
item.description: Experts said the world remains far from meeting international goals on climate change.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS and DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Zimmerman Is Charged With Aggravated Assault
item.description: George Zimmerman, who was acquitted in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager, was arrested after a dispute with his girlfriend, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN BLINDER
item.media:description: George Zimmerman was charged with domestic aggravated assault and other counts after, officials said, he and his girlfriend had an argument at the home they shared in Apopka, Fla.
